Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Understanding the Nature of Turbulent Fluctuations in the Near Sun Solar Wind
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a 2-year postgraduate fellowship research project to study turbulence in the near-Sun plasma and its role in solar corona heating and in solar wind acceleration. The project aims both to predict the qualitative properties of the turbulent fluctuations that will be measured in situ by the upcoming ESA/ Solar Probe Plus and NASA/ Solar Orbiter missions near and within the Alfven critical point and to create a theoretical framework for the interpretation of these measurements. Utilizing the ?synthetic spacecraft data method? developed by the PI during his graduate research, together with various turbulence and coronal heating models, three specific objectives will be pursued: 1) Quantifying changes in the measured power spectra near and within the Alfvenic critical point due to the violation of Taylor's Hypothesis and using these changes to verify the presence of whistler and/or kinetic Alfven waves; 2) Compiling a set of observable signatures which can be used with in situ observations to distinguish between various coronal heating mechanisms; and 3) Using nonlinear simulations as a separate check of the validity of the synthetic data method. The work will be carried out at University of New Hampshire under the mentorship of Professor Chandran.

The role of turbulence in plasma heating and acceleration are fundamental plasma physics problems that are of interest to a broad scientific community working on astrophysical plasmas (e.g. accretion disks and magnetospheres of young stars), space physics (e.g. solar wind and planetary magnetospheres), and laboratory plasmas (e.g. fusion reactors). The work will be done by a recent Ph.D. graduate as his introduction into a teaching and research career in the geospace community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, "Understanding the Nature of Turbulent Fluctuations in the Near Sun Solar Wind", produced theoretical predictions for a variety of important processes which govern the solar wind, a hot, low density plasma, which is accelerated from the Sun's surface and fills the solar system. Two soon to be launched spacecraft, Solar Probe Plus and Solar Orbiter, will provide novel measurements of the solar wind near to the Sun, an environment that has not previously been measured locally. To insure that as much scientific insight can be extracted from these measurements as possible, we have studied issues with interpretation of the local observations, and have modeled observable signatures of two classes of mechanisms which may extract energy from electromagnetic fields and heat the solar wind ions and electrons.

Typical sequences of solar wind measurements of the type made for the last half-century of the space age near the Earth can be transformed from tracing out a sequence of consecutive times to a sequence of consecutive positions. This transformation, known as the 'Taylor Hypothesis', has been shown to be valid as long as the solar wind flow speeds are faster than the characteristic time scales over which the system evolves, which is typically true in the solar wind near the Earth. Closer to the Sun, the solar wind flow speed decreases while the characteristic evolution time becomes faster. Near Solar Probe Plus' closest encounter with the Sun, this inequality will break, potentially leading to problems interpreting the data the spacecraft records. We have developed a modified version of the Taylor Hypothesis which takes into account the predicted behavior of magnetic and velocity fluctuations near the Sun to preserve the equivalence between temporal and spatial time series for the dominant component of the solar wind. Such a modification is essential to interpreting these novel measurements. The approximations used in constructing this modified hypothesis are listed so that when Solar Probe Plus reports back its measurements, we will be able to confirm whether or not the modified hypothesis can be applied.

Several classes of mechanisms have been proposed to extract energy from turbulence electromagnetic fluctuations and heat the solar wind plasma. We have modeled the effects of two of these mechanisms; coherent, or resonant, wave-particle interactions, and stochastic ion heating by low-frequency turbulence. For both models, we have constructed observable signatures so that local measurements of the solar wind, both by Solar Probe Plus as well as other spacecraft, may be able to verify or falsify the presence of these mechanisms.  These models have been tested by a number of numerical calculations and nonlinear simulations, and are now ready to be applied to spacecraft measurements. By looking for these observational signatures in solar wind data, we hope to be able to identify which mechanisms operate under what conditions. This improved characterization of the solar wind is important for constructing a better understanding of the heliosphere, Earth's home in the universe.
